children.name: (1.1) apply phonic knowledge and skills as the route to decode words
(1.2) respond speedily with the correct sound to graphemes (letters or groups of letters) for all 40+ phonemes, including, where applicable, alternative sounds for graphemes
(1.3) read accurately by blending sounds in unfamiliar words containing GPCs that have been taught
(1.4) read common exception words, noting unusual correspondences between spelling and sound and where these occur in the word
(1.5) read words containing taught GPCs and –s, –es, –ing, –ed, –er and –est endings
(1.6) read other words of more than one syllable that contain taught GPCs
(1.7) read words with contractions [for example, I’m, I’ll, we’ll], and understand that the apostrophe represents the omitted letter(s)
(1.8) read aloud accurately books that are consistent with their developing phonic knowledge and that do not require them to use other strategies to work out words
(1.9) re-read these books to build up their fluency and confidence in word reading.
(2.1) develop pleasure in reading, motivation to read, vocabulary and understanding by:
(2.1.1) listening to and discussing a wide range of poems, stories and non-fiction at a level beyond that at which they can read independently
(2.1.2) being encouraged to link what they read or hear read to their own experiences
(2.1.3) becoming very familiar with key stories, fairy stories and traditional tales, retelling them and considering their particular characteristics
(2.1.4) recognising and joining in with predictable phrases
(2.1.5) learning to appreciate rhymes and poems, and to recite some by heart
(2.1.6) discussing word meanings, linking new meanings to those already known
(2.2) understand both the books they can already read accurately and fluently and those they listen to by:
(2.2.1) drawing on what they already know or on background information and vocabulary provided by the teacher
(2.2.2) checking that the text makes sense to them as they read and correcting inaccurate reading
(2.2.3) discussing the significance of the title and events
(2.2.4) making inferences on the basis of what is being said and done
(2.2.5) predicting what might happen on the basis of what has been read so far
(2.3) participate in discussion about what is read to them, taking turns and listening to what others say
(2.4) explain clearly their understanding of what is read to them.
(3.S) Spelling
(3.S.1) spell:
(3.S.1.a) words containing each of the 40+ phonemes already taught
(3.S.2) name the letters of the alphabet:
(3.S.3) add prefixes and suffixes:
(3.H) Handwriting
(3.H.1) sit correctly at a table, holding a pencil comfortably and correctly
(3.H.2) begin to form lower-case letters in the correct direction, starting and finishing in the right place
(3.H.3) form capital letters
(4.1) write sentences by:
(5.1) develop their understanding of the concepts set out in English Appendix 2 by:
(5.1.1) leaving spaces between words
(5.1.2) joining words and joining clauses using and
(5.1.3) beginning to punctuate sentences using a capital letter and a full stop, question mark or exclamation mark

Understand new vocabulary in context: Ask questions to reveal character
Understand new vocabulary in context: Model the key strategy of retelling the sequence of events in the drama
Understand new vocabulary in context: Model the key strategy of identifying cause-and-effect relationships
Understand and use base words and inflected endings
Understand related words
Visualise characters by exploring voice and gesture

nodes.statement: Languages have different written communication systems.
Oral language can be used to clarify.
Language is used to express likes and dislikes.
Patterns of language interaction signal social roles and relationships.
Visual forms of language are a distinct mode of communication with specific features.
Oral language can be used to persuade.
Languages have different visual transporation systems.
Spoken words are made up of syllables.
Different forms of communication technologies are available for people with hearing and visual impairments, and other disabilities.
Different systems of communication cater to different needs and purposes.
Patterns of language interaction vary across social contexts.
Oral language can be used to inform.
Understand that the position and size of letters helps develop consistent printing. 'modified'
Oral language can be used to entertain.
Spoken syllables are made up of sounds (phonemes).

filters.name: Domain
options: Social Work / Family Therapy / Human Services

nodes.framework-element: Demonstrate knowledge of sociological vocabulary, concepts, history, theories, and theorists.
Evaluate the sources of social change and social movements.
Describe the interactions and relationships between individuals, groups, social structures, and social institutions.
Demonstrate critical thinking skills through writing and oral communication in a variety of formats.
Compare and contrast the sociological characteristics of diverse cultures and societies in the United States and the world.
Analyze social and economic inequalities in the United States and the world.
Demonstrate knowledge of research methods, data collection and analysis, and quantitative literacy.
Apply a sociological perspective to making informed decisions about everyday life and opportunities.
Use information literacy skills to critically evaluate articles and data from a sociological perspective.

node_filters.name: Webb’s Depth of Knowledge Cognitive Complexity Dimensions

curriculum.product-name: Thinking About Women: Sociological Perspectives on Sex and Gender

children.name: 1.1 What Is the Sociological Imagination
1.2 What Are Social Contexts
1.3 Where Did Sociology Come From
2.1 What Do Social Theorists Seek to Explain?
2.2 How Did the Early Social Theorists Make Sense of the World?
2.3 What Innovations in Social Theory Emerged in the Mid-Twentieth Century?
2.4 How Has a New Generation of Social Theory Evolved?
3.1 Where Do Sociological Questions Come From?
3.2 What Is the Best Method to Research a Sociological Question?
3.3 What Challenges Do Sociologists Face When Collecting Data?
3.4 How Do Sociologists Make Sense of Their Findings?
4.1  How Do We Develop a Sense of Self?
4.2  How Do We Make Sense of Our Worlds?
4.3  What Challenges Do We Face as We Move from One Social Context to Another?
5.1 What Is Social Structure?
5.2 How Do Roles and Social Hierarchies Shape Our Life Chances?
5.3 How Do Norms and Institutions Influence Social Life?
5.4 How Do Social Structures Influence Our Daily Lives and Social Interactions?
5.5 Why Are Social Structures Slow to Change?
6.1 What Is Culture?
6.2  How Does Culture Shape Our Collective Identity?
6.3 How Do Our Cultural Practices Relate to Class and Status?
6.4 Who Produces Culture, and Why?
6.5 What Is the Relationship between Media and Democracy?
7.1 What Are the Distinct Forms of Power?
7.2  What Is the State, and How Does It Distribute Power in a Society?
7.3 Who Has Power in the United States Today?
8.1 How Do Social Factors Impact Markets?
8.2  Why Are Organizations Important for Social and Economic Life?
8.3  What Is the Relationship between Organizations and Their External Environment?
8.4  How Is Work Inside Organizations Structured?
8.5  How Do We Measure Work Satisfaction?
9.1 What Draws People to Cities?
9.2 How Do Neighborhoods Form and Change?
9.3 How Do Cities Influence Who We Are, Who Our Friends Are, and How We Live?
9.4 Why Are So Many Social Problems Found in Cities?
9.5 How Will Cities Change in an Increasingly Connected World?
10.1  What Is Inequality?
10.2  Why Is America So Unequal?
10.3  Do We All Have an Equal Opportunity to Succeed in Life?
10.4 How Much Poverty Exists in the United States and around the World?

nodes.Educational Objective: Discuss how a sociological imagination helps to challenge stereotypes.
Explain the process for forming sociological questions.
Identify the types of questions that sociologists are particularly well equipped to explore.
Discuss the wide range of topics and areas of life that sociologists study.
Analyze how families and communities shape the social development of children.
Explain how our identities impact our opportunities in life.
Discuss how the schools and organizations we participate in shape our lives and identities.
Analyze the ways in which the social and economic contexts we are born into shape the opportunities available to us.
Explain the distinction between social interaction and social structure.
Discuss the origins of sociology as a discipline.
Explain the roles of industrialization and urbanization in the development of sociology.
Compare and contrast sociology with the other social sciences.
Identify some of the spin-off fields that originally started in sociology.
Define social theory and describe the range of different social theories.
Identify the three common themes that all of the major sociological theories have sought to address.
Discuss why Marx believed that societies were so heavily shaped by their economic systems.
Analyze Emile Durkheim’s explanation of what holds societies together.
Discuss Max Weber’s contributions to our understanding of motivations for behavior, legitimacy and authority, and status groups and social closure.
Explain how Georg Simmel’s insights on social circles and social distance help us understand how individuals and groups relate to one another.
Explain W. E. B. Du Bois’s views of the diverse ways in which racism influences the lives of African Americans and how racism produces a double consciousness.
Discuss the roles that norms, values, and institutions play in society, according to the theory of structural functionalism.
Discuss how conflict theory attempted to explain social inequalities.
Analyze how everyday social interaction lies at the heart of understanding society, according to symbolic interactionism.
Discuss neo-Marxist ideas about the capitalist state, social classes, and globalization.
Analyze the role of intersectionality in theories of gender inequality.
Explain Foucault’s theory of how power operates in society.
Discuss how Bourdieu redefined classes and the nature of class differences.
Discuss how sociologists operationalize their research questions and distinguish between independent and dependent variables.
Identify the steps of the classical scientific method, and explain why sociologists might take a looser approach to research.
Compare and contrast quantitative versus qualitative research methods.
Identify the key strengths and weaknesses of survey and interview methods.
Explain why the main strength of ethnography is also its central weakness.
Identify the types of research questions that are best studied from a comparative–historical perspective.
Explain why choosing the right research method to study motivations and behavior is a complex process.
Explain sampling issues that sociologists grapple with when they begin their research.
Compare and contrast reliability and validity and explain their importance in sociological research.
Explain why the ability to make causal inferences is so important yet challenging for sociologists.
Identify the goal of data analysis and describe the process sociologists use to interpret research.
Explain how sociologists use generalization to draw conclusions from their research.
Explain how the opinions and judgments of others shape our identities.
Compare and contrast the roles that significant others, reference groups, and generalized others play in guiding our behavior and in shaping our sense of self.
Discuss how we differ in the ways we present ourselves to others.
Explain how context gives meaning to words and situations.
Identify some of the methods we use when interacting in public.
Identify the causes of role conflict.
Explain how a self-fulfilling prophecy can influence label formation.
Identify the role of informal rules in social interaction.
Explain what makes people conform and how conformity impacts how we live together.
Explain how social structure is similar to the structure of a tall building.
Identify the two key components of social structure.
Distinguish between roles we choose for ourselves and social hierarchies.
Explain how social hierarchies arise and persist.
Discuss the roles that power and privilege play in social hierarchies.
Explain the impact that population size has on the ways in which groups within a social hierarchy relate to one another.
Distinguish between social norms and formal rules of behavior.
Explain the process of institutionalization and identify examples of common practices that have been institutionalized.
Explain why large formal organizations are critically important to the overall structure of a society.
Discuss how socialization contributes to the creation of roles and norms.
Discuss how social structure exerts influence over our interactions with others.
Discuss the relative impact of social structure versus individual choice.
Explain how past outcomes impact present choices.
Analyze the power of path-dependent processes.
Define culture from a sociological perspective.
Explain how a group's symbols can be considered its culture, and give examples of collective symbols of contemporary U.S. culture.
Describe how our values and beliefs influence how we live our lives.
Explain the ways in which culture is a form of communication.
Discuss the role that culture plays in establishing group style, and explain what distinguishes a subculture from the mainstream.

nodes.Descriptor: Can use a suitable phrase to a in a discussion on a familiar topic.
nodes.Source Descriptor: Can intervene in a discussion on a familiar topic, using a suitable phrase to get the floor. (CEFR) | Can intervene appropriately in discussion, exploiting a variety of suitable language to do so. (North)

nodes.Descriptor: Can follow the main points of extended discussion around them if in standard speech.

nodes.Descriptor: Can understand the main points of narratives and conversations about familiar topics (e.g. work, leisure) delivered in clear standard speech.
nodes.Source Descriptor: Can understand the main points of clear standard speech on familiar matters regularly encountered in work, school, leisure etc., including short narratives. (CEFR)

nodes.Source Descriptor: Can describe everyday aspects of his environment e.g. people, places, a job or study experience. (CEFR)

nodes.Descriptor: Can write a description of a future event or activity.

nodes.Descriptor: Can write emails/letters exchanging information, emphasising the most important point.
nodes.Source Descriptor: Can write personal letters and notes asking for or conveying simple information of immediate relevance, getting across the point he/she feels to be important (CEFR)

nodes.Descriptor: Can signal contrast in a simple text with a limited range of language.
nodes.NOTES: Apriil 2015 IRT Analysis Changes. Previous Score/CEFR were 42 - A2+ -  Previous status was Published  -  Reasons for other changes -

nodes.Descriptor: Can use a suitable phrase to invite others into a discussion.
nodes.Source Descriptor: Can repeat back part of what someone has said to confirm mutual understanding and help keep the development of ideas on course. Can invite others into the discussion. (CEFR)

nodes.Descriptor: No grammar descriptor available
Can use 'get/have' to refer to having things done by other people.
nodes.Example: I’m having my flat painted.; I've just had my car repaired.
nodes.Structure: have/get' + NP + past participle for impersonal agency

nodes.Descriptor: Can correctly use 'a bit/a little' and 'a few' to refer to quantities with mass and count nouns respectively.
nodes.Example: There's a little/a bit of cheese in the fridge.; I've got a few ideas.; We need a little/a bit of help here.; They bought a few books.
nodes.Structure: a bit/a little/a few' + mass (uncountable) vs. count quantities

nodes.Descriptor: Can use the present continuous to refer to changing situations.
nodes.Example: Prices are going up.; He’s getting better.; It’s getting colder.; We’re getting hungry.

nodes.Descriptor: Can use conjunctions such as 'when' and 'before' with the present simple, with future reference.
nodes.Example: I’ll tell her when I see her.; I’ll call as soon as I get there.; I’ll do it before I leave.
nodes.Structure: when/as soon as/before', etc. + present simple with future reference

nodes.Descriptor: Can use possessive pronouns as objects and complements.
nodes.Example: These are ours.; Let’s go to theirs.; I don’t like hers.; I gave him his.

nodes.Descriptor: Can use a range of common time markers for the past, present and future.
nodes.Example: ago; last night/week; yesterday; right now; at the moment; next Saturday/week
nodes.Structure: time markers for past, present and future

nodes.Descriptor: Can give, deny or ask about permission in the future with 'will/won't be able to/allowed to'.
nodes.Example: They'll be able to swim every day.; We won't be allowed to drive there.
nodes.Structure: will/won't be able/allowed to' + VPinf for permission

nodes.Descriptor: Can make statements and ask questions with 'know (that)' + complement clauses.
nodes.Example: I didn't know (that) she was still married.; We know (that) you don't like us.

nodes.Descriptor: Can make statements about appearance using 'seem/appear like/that' with complement clauses.
nodes.Example: It looks like he isn't coming.; It appears that John has misunderstood.

nodes.Descriptor: Can use language related to accessories, cosmetics and hair
nodes.Example: amethyst, jewelled, buff, amber, aquamarine, braid

nodes.Descriptor: Can use language related to accessories, cosmetics and hair
Can use language related to advertising and brands
Can use language related to advertising and brands
Can use language related to advice, orders, and instructions
Can use language related to alcohol, smoking and drugs
Can use language related to alcohol, smoking and drugs

Can use language related to address and telephone
Can use language related to amusement
